I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2002 Country Programming Mission, the Government of the Philippines 
confirmed its request to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help implement the Health 
Sector Reform Agenda (HSRA) developed by the Department of Health (DOH). This request 
meets ADB's health sector priorities to enhance access to essential health services for the poor. 
A Fact-Finding Mission in August 2002 reached understanding with the Government on the 
objective, scope, budget and implementation arrangements for the technical assistance (TA).1  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  While the health of the Filipinos has significantly improved over the last 50 years, many 
challenges remain. In recent years, improvements in health status have lagged. Large variations 
in health status persist across population groups mainly due to poor coverage of public health 
and primary care services. There is unequal access to health services due to geographic and 
financial barriers. Inadequate funding and management systems limit the impact of the public 
health programs. Allocation of available funding is inefficient and inequitable. Curative health 
facilities are either inadequate or inappropriate. With devolution, the lack of coordination among 
local government units (LGUs) has sometimes compromised the effectiveness of the health 
care delivery system at the local level. 
 
3.  About 75 Filipinos die from tuberculosis every day and an estimated 270,000 new cases 
are identified every year. The directly observed treatment strategy (DOTS) promoted by DOH 
reaches almost 100% of the public health care providers, but with 30–40% of all tuberculosis 
patients probably consulting private health care providers, the private sector has a significant 
role  to  play  in  the  program.  Reproductive  health  strategies  encompass  safe  motherhood, 
adolescent health, prevention of sexually transmitted diseases including HIV/AIDS,2 and access 
to family planning. All these issues need to be carefully addressed so that the poor who do not 
have easy access to the private sector and rely mostly on the public health programs to cover 
their reproductive health needs receive tangible benefits. 
 
4.  The majority of the poor rely on public (government) health services, which are free or 
low-cost. But public health services, particularly curative services at the primary health care 
(PHC) level, are considered of poor quality and do not adequately meet the needs of the poor. 
The number of doctors in PHC facilities is very low, and medical supplies (including drugs) are 
often not available. Frequently the patient purchases the necessary supplies from the market. 
Many patients bypass PHC services to go directly to secondary and tertiary hospitals. As a 
result, patients that could be treated at PHC facilities at much lower cost overburden higher 
level facilities. To improve the health care delivery system, there is a need to improve PHC 
curative services, and guarantee the availability of essential drugs and medical supplies. 
 
5.  Under the Local Government Code, which came into effect in 1992, LGUs—provinces, 
cities and municipalities—are responsible for financing and managing most of the public health 
care facilities. Devolution of health services to the LGUs resulted in fragmentation of the public 
health care system, with poor coordination among the various levels of health care facilities 
independently managed by different LGUs. Ten years after devolution, the performance of 
provincial and district hospitals and of the public health services delivery system in general is

considered  unsatisfactory.  Financial  resources  are  often  insufficient  for  operating  and 
maintaining hospitals. LGUs often complain that the meager Internal Revenue Allocation they 
receive does not allow them to provide reasonable health care services. But lack of local 
capacity, weak supervision, and inadequate management guidelines also have had an impact 
on the quality of the health care delivery system under devolution. 
 
6.  To address these problems, DOH developed in 1999 the HSRA, a comprehensive 
approach to reform the health sector in five related areas: social health insurance, hospital 
reforms, public health programs, health regulation, and local health systems. HSRA aims to 
improve the health system by (i) mobilizing new resources and targeting the Government's 
subsidies  on  the  poor  under  a  social  health  insurance  system,  (ii)  improving  hospital 
management,  (iii)  ensuring  funding  and  improving  essential  public  health  programs,  (iv) 
strengthening health regulations, and (v) developing the local health systems and reap the full 
benefits of devolution.3 While DOH can provide leadership and technical support, the successful 
implementation of HSRA now depends on the participation and support of the LGUs. 
 
7.  The  five  reform  areas  of  HSRA  are  interdependent  and  require  simultaneous 
implementation.  With  a  functioning  social  health  insurance  system,  the  Government  can 
subsidize the health insurance premium of the poor, while those who can afford to pay will pay 
their own premium. Government subsidies will no longer be targeted to health care facilities, but 
to the poor directly. To ensure that those who can afford to pay for health services are also 
willing to pay for them, the quality of the services must improve. Health facilities must be 
upgraded, the necessary medical equipment provided, and quality control in health services 
ensured. With better managed hospitals and new resources mobilized through health insurance, 
the national Government and the LGUs will be able to allocate more resources to public health 
programs.4 Health regulations and their enforcement are important mechanisms to guarantee 
the quality of the health services. All these reforms need to be implemented in the local health 
systems, with the support of the LGUs. 
 
8.  Implementing HSRA will require significant investment. DOH has opted for progressive 
implementation, starting in selected convergence sites5 where existing conditions–in particular, 
interest  and  support  of  the  LGUs  for  improving  local  health  services–should  facilitate 
implementation of the interrelated reforms of HSRA.  
 
9.  A number of interventions directly or indirectly related to the implementation of HSRA 
have been completed or are ongoing. There  is a felt need to take stock of what has been 
undertaken and review lessons learned to further improve the implementation of HSRA.  
 
10.  DOH has requested its development partners to continue supporting the implementation 
of HSRA, and to provide assistance at the national level and in selected convergence sites. 
German Agency for Technical Cooperation (GTZ) and the World Bank have already started 
preparing their programs of assistance.6 At the national level, the World Bank will strengthen the

guidelines, and to regulate the quality of drugs. GTZ will continue its technical support for health 
insurance for the poor and the provision of essential drugs to communities. In parallel, GTZ and 
the World Bank will assist selected convergence sites.7 
 
11.  DOH has requested ADB's assistance to contribute to health sector reforms and support 
programs in selected convergence sites. DOH has selected a preliminary list of 11 convergence 
sites for possible ADB support.8 DOH has also requested ADB's assistance to review and 
assess the public health programs, a major component of HSRA. Two programs are of high 
priority for DOH: the reproductive health program and the program against tuberculosis, which 
are of particular significance for the poor. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
12.  The TA aims (i) to strengthen DOH capability to implement HSRA by reviewing its 
current status and assessing unmet needs, and (ii) to prepare a feasibility study for a project 
proposal to support the implementation of HSRA. The TA will be implemented in two phases 
and address both policy issues and investment requirements. The first phase will consist of a 
comprehensive review of various projects and studies related to HSRA and an assessment of 
the gaps and requirements to successfully implement HSRA. The second phase will prepare a 
detailed project proposal to support implementation of HSRA in selected convergence sites and 
strengthen DOH's public health programs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  Several projects have supported and tested various aspects of HSRA. In the first phase, 
a team of consultants will undertake a comprehensive review of these projects, paying special 
attention  to  their  impact  on  the  poor.  Among  others,  the  team  will  consolidate  available 
information on the progress of reforms in the following areas: integrated health planning system, 
hospital  management  information  system,  and  health  financing  systems;9  social  health 
insurance and local health networking; partnership mechanisms with LGUs and nongovernment 
organizations (NGO);10 incentive schemes for improving the health performance of LGUs; and 
community-based  social  health  insurance  schemes  for  the  informal  sector.  Some  DOH 
initiatives such as the hospitals as Centers for Wellness, the Sentrong Sigla11 accreditation for 
public health facilities, and the development of inter-local health zones will also be reviewed. 
 
14.  The consultants will identify policy issues related to poverty targeting that need to be 
further addressed by HSRA and make appropriate recommendations. The team will analyze the 
role  of  the  regional  centers  (Centers  for  Health  Development),  assess  capacity  and  skill 
requirements of the LGUs for implementing HSRA, and identify mechanisms to strengthen 
public  health  programs,  particularly  reproductive  health  (including  family  planning)  and

tuberculosis  control  and  prevention,  under  HSRA.  The  team  will  assess  the  prospect  for 
pursuing successful initiatives, and identify priority investments, giving priority to the health 
needs of the poor. 
 
15.  At the end of the first phase, the consultants will submit to DOH and ADB a mid-term 
report to be discussed at a tripartite meeting. The report will describe the specific objectives that 
an ensuing project supported by an ADB loan will want to achieve. The report will also propose 
selection criteria to identify provinces that are most ready as convergence sites, and provide 
detailed information related to these criteria for the 11 provinces pre-selected by DOH. The 
consultants will in particular assess the respective LGUs' commitment to HSRA and their 
willingness and capacity to share the cost of implementing it. Five convergence sites will be 
selected for a feasibility study.  
 
16.  In the second phase, the consultants will conduct a feasibility study in the 5 selected 
convergence sites and develop a project proposal for possible ADB financing. The feasibility 
study will first identify local health needs and priorities through participatory workshops involving 
all stakeholders: beneficiaries, decision-makers and health services providers. The consultants 
will also develop a set of technical, economic and financial criteria for identifying HSRA-related 
policy reforms and investments, which will ensure that the poor will be the main beneficiaries of 
the ensuing project. A project proposal will then be developed and discussed at stakeholders’ 
workshops. The consolidated proposal will provide detailed information on the proposed project, 
including cost estimates and implementation arrangements. Financing mechanisms, counterpart 
funds requirements and cost sharing mechanisms between the national Government and the 
concerned LGUs will need to be determined in a tripartite meeting (Government, ADB, and 
consultants).12 The recommendations of this meeting will be included in the final report. 
 
17.  The methodology will rely on building partnerships and participation. On DOH's request, 
all  development  partners  are  involved  in  supporting  HSRA  (para.  10).  There  is  good 
collaboration among the aid agencies and DOH, which will be tapped to improve quality of 
project design, avoid duplication, and ensure complementarity. After convergence sites have 
been  selected  for  a  project  proposal,  the  consulting  team  will  ensure  that  the  project  is 
developed by the concerned LGUs with participation of all stakeholders. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $860,000 equivalent, comprising $151,000 in 
foreign currency and $709,000 equivalent in local currency. It is proposed that ADB provide a 
grant of $600,000 equivalent to meet the entire foreign currency cost and $449,000 equivalent 
of the local currency costs. The TA  will be financed by ADB on a grant basis from the Japan 
Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will provide support 
facilities, counterpart staff, office facilities, administrative support, and other logistical support 
including local ground transportation, the cost of which is estimated to total $260,000 equivalent. 
The Government assured the availability of counterpart services, facilities, and funds by the 
expected starting date of the TA. Details of the cost estimate and financing plan are in Appendix 
1. The Government has been advised that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to financing 
any ensuing project.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  DOH will be the Executing Agency for the TA. An international consulting firm will be 
engaged to provide 5 person-months of international consulting services and 36 person-months 
of  domestic  consulting  services  using  the  simplified  technical  proposal  procedure.  The 
consulting team will include international consultants with expertise in health sector reforms, 
health economics and public-private partnership; and domestic experts with expertise in health 
sector reforms, public health, project financial analysis, organizational development, health 
infrastructure, environmental impact assessment, public-private partnership, social marketing, 
and  poverty  analysis.  The  consulting  firm  will  recruit  facilitators  for  the  social  marketing 
campaign and for participatory workshops. Outline terms of reference are in Appendix 2. ADB 
will engage the consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and 
other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. Funds will also be 
allocated for office equipment, surveys, and participatory workshops. 
 
20.  During  the  first  phase,  advocacy  workshops  on  HSRA  and  TA  objectives  will  be 
organized for various groups of stakeholders in the 11 pre-selected provinces assisted by 
facilitators  with  experience  in  social  marketing.  During  the  second  phase  of  the  TA,  the 
consultants will organize a series of participatory workshops in the selected convergence sites 
assisted by experienced facilitators. After consulting with all stakeholders on their needs and 
priorities, the consultants will develop draft project proposals for each convergence site to be 
discussed  with  stakeholders.13  A  national  workshop  at  the  end  of  the  second  phase  will 
consolidate LGU-related subprojects into one project proposal. The consultants are expected to 
begin working in the field in April 2003. The TA will be implemented over about 6 months and is 
expected to be completed by November 2003.  
 
21.  The Government will establish a steering committee comprising DOH and the oversight 
agencies (National Economic Development Authority, Department of Finance and Department 
of  Budget  and  Management)  to  provide  policy  guidance  and  overall  direction.  The  DOH 
Undersecretary for External Affairs will chair the committee and act as project director for the 
TA. DOH's technical coordinating group, established to monitor implementation of HSRA,14 will 
be expanded to include representatives of other stakeholders (in particular, the Centers for 
Health Development and the LGUs), and will be responsible for ensuring the technical integrity 
of the TA output. The director of DOH's Health Policy Development and Planning Bureau will 
coordinate TA implementation as TA project Manager. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Philippines for preparing the Health Sector Development Project, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A team of consultants will be engaged to help the Government review and assess the 
various ongoing and completed interventions and studies related to the Health Sector Reform 
Agenda (HSRA). During a second phase, the consultants will prepare a feasibility study to 
implement HSRA in selected convergence sites. Consulting services will be provided by an 
international consulting firm, selected in accordance with ADB’s  Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants.  
 
1.  Health Sector Reform Specialists 
  
2.  Two experts in health sector reforms will be engaged: one international consultant  – 
team leader for 3 months and one domestic consultant – deputy team leader for 5 months. 
 
3.  The two consultants will 
(i)  review HSRA and the related technical, legal, and administrative documents 
produced by DOH and other sources with a focus on adequate poverty targeting; 
(ii)  review and analyze the various completed and ongoing interventions related to 
HSRA supported by development partners or initiated by DOH in terms of their 
poverty focus; 
(iii)  encourage and compile policy recommendations of the other members of the 
team in their respective areas of expertise regarding the implementation of HSRA 
particularly in the area of poverty targeting; 
(iv)  identify strengths and weaknesses of HSRA, areas requiring clarifications and/or 
strengthening, and implementation problems. In particular, review the status of 
the regional centers, the capacity requirements of the LGUs to implement HSRA, 
and the effectiveness of the public health programs under HSRA, focusing on 
reproductive health and tuberculosis control and prevention; and 
(v)  make appropriate recommendations to strengthen the poverty focus of HSRA, 
facilitate its implementation, and expand successful initiatives, particularly with 
regards to the regional centers, LGUs capacity and public health programs. 
 
4.  During the feasibility study, the consultants will 
 (i)  assess  strengths,  weaknesses,  opportunities,  and  threats  for  implementing 
HSRA in each of the selected convergence sites; 
(ii)  identify  actions  to  strengthen  the  poverty  focus,  technical  assistance  (TA) 
packages, and investments for each selected convergence site, and develop a 
proposal to address the identified requirements; and 
(iii)  prepare an action plan for implementing the proposal. 
 
5.  The team leader and deputy team leader will 
(i)  coordinate team activities, consolidate the various inputs of the team in the 
reports and the proposals, and ensure a smooth implementation of the TA; 
(ii)  coordinate with the Government, DOH, and local government units at all levels 
(cities, municipalities, provinces, and regions); 
(iii)  ensure coordination with development partners active in the Philippines health 
sector,  particularly  with  the  World  Bank  and  German  Agency  for  Technical 
Cooperation (GTZ) that are preparing similar projects; 
(iv)  in collaboration with the social marketing specialist and the poverty and social 
analysis  specialist,  organize  a  series  of  participatory  workshops  to  ensure

information and consultation of all stakeholders during project preparation. A 
group of facilitators will be recruited to assist in implementing the workshops; 
(v)  develop criteria to identify provinces that are most ready to implement HSRA as 
convergence sites, and provide detailed information related to these criteria on 
the 11 provinces pre-selected by DOH; 
(vi)  assist DOH and ADB in selecting the convergence sites for the feasibility study; 
(vii)  prepare a comprehensive project framework according to ADB guidelines for the 
feasibility study; 
(viii)  prepare, in collaboration with the whole team, a comprehensive project proposal 
including (i) detailed cost estimates, (ii) implementation arrangements, and (iii) 
appropriate monitoring and evaluation indicators and mechanisms; 
(ix)  brief the TA project officer in the Asian Development Bank (ADB) once a week 
about progress made; and 
(x)  ensure timely preparation and submission of the requested reports, as well as 
ensure the quality and completeness of the reports. 
 
2.  Health Economist 
 
6.  One international health economist will be engaged for 2 months. The consultant will 
(i)  determine the rationale, nature, and coverage of public interventions in the health 
sector in the Philippines; 
(ii)  review and analyze cost recovery and pricing issues in delivering health services 
under HSRA, considering that some health services are public goods and others 
not. The consultant will assess the existing pricing and subsidy strategies and 
mechanisms and develop appropriate recommendations to improve equity and 
cost-efficiency for poverty reduction; 
(iii)  analyze the demand for health services in the selected convergence sites; and 
(iv)  conduct  a  comprehensive  economic  impact  analysis  of  the  project  proposal 
developed during the feasibility study, including cost-benefit analysis, sensitivity 
and risk analysis. These analyses, conducted in collaboration with the financial 
analyst and the consultant for poverty impact assessment, will be guided by 
ADB’s Handbook for the Economic Analysis of Health Sector Projects (August 
2000) and ADB's Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact in Economic Analysis 
of Project (July 2000). 
 
3.  Public Health Specialist  
 
7.  One domestic consultant specialized in public health will be engaged for 3 months to 
assess the public health programs of DOH, in particular the reproductive health (including family 
planning and maternal nutrition) program and the program against tuberculosis. 
 
8.  The consultant will 
(i)  prepare a detailed assessment of the existing public health programs and the 
impact of devolution on these programs; 
(ii)  assess the impact of HSRA on the public health programs; 
(iii)  assess the risks and opportunities of HSRA for the public health programs; and 
(iv)  develop appropriate recommendations to improve the quality, effectiveness and 
efficiency of the public health programs.

9.  Working in the selected convergence sites during the feasibility study, the specialist will 
 (i)  develop and supervise the implementation of a survey to collect data on the most 
common health problems, stratified by income level, in collaboration with the 
poverty and social analysis specialist; 
(ii)  review the existing public health programs;  
(iii)  develop appropriate recommendations to improve the quality, effectiveness and 
efficiency of the public health programs in the selected convergence sites; and 
(iv)  prepare a plan of action to implement these recommendations. 
 
4.  Specialist in Public-Private Partnership in the Health Sector  
 
10.  A domestic expert for public-private partnerships in the health sector will be engaged for 
2 months. The consultant will 
(i)  review and describe the public and the private health sectors in the Philippines; 
(ii)  examine the constraints to, and opportunities for, developing an efficient public-
private partnership in the Philippines health sector; 
(iii)  make  a  detailed  assessment  of  HSRA  on  facilitating  or  preventing  the 
development of an efficient public-private partnership in the health sector; and 
(iv)  develop appropriate recommendations to strengthen public-private partnership in 
the health sector in the Philippines, with the objective of raising the quality and 
efficiency of services in the health sector. 
 
11.  During the second phase, in the selected convergence sites, the consultant will 
(i)  prepare a detailed analysis of the public and the private health sectors;  
(ii)  develop appropriate recommendations to facilitate public-private partnership in 
the health sector, focusing on the needs of the poor; and 
(iii)  develop an appropriate plan of action to implement the recommendations. 
 
5.  Organizational Development Specialist  
 
12.  One domestic expert in organizational development will be engaged for 2 months. The 
consultant will analyze and assess the Philippines health system and develop appropriate 
recommendations to increase effectiveness and cost-efficiency, improve service quality and 
facilitate participation of the patients and beneficiaries in identifying health needs and solutions. 
The  consultant  will  pay  particular  attention  to  the  referral  health  system  with  its  primary, 
secondary, and tertiary levels of health care services, and to organizational development at the 
health facilities (hospitals) level. The goal is to develop an efficient, high-quality local health 
system that meets the needs and the demands of the population, in particular of the poor. 
 
6.  Health Infrastructure Specialist 
 
13.  One domestic expert in health infrastructure will be engaged for 2 months. During the 
second phase of the TA, the consultant will assess the need for upgrading/rehabilitating health 
facilities  in  the  selected  convergence  sites.  The  consultant  will  then  develop  the  related 
technical proposal with detailed cost-estimates and implementation schedule. 
 
7.  Environmental Impact Assessment Specialist 
 
14.  A domestic expert in environmental impact assessment will be engaged for 2 months 
during the second phase. In collaboration with the health infrastructure specialist, the consultant 
will prepare an initial environmental impact assessment for the civil works proposed  by the

health infrastructure specialist in the selected convergence sites. The consultant will prepare the 
necessary recommendations to address environmental concerns adequately, in accordance 
with ADB's Guidelines on Environmental Impact Assessment. 
 
8.  Financial Analyst 
 
15.  One domestic financial analyst will be engaged for 2.5 months. The consultant will 
prepare a financial analysis, financial projections, and an institutional assessment in accordance 
with ADB's Guidelines for the Financial Governance and Management of Investment Projects 
Financed by the Asian Development Bank. The scope of work includes, but is not limited to, the 
following: 
(i)  review the financial policies and financial management systems of the proposed 
Executing Agency, identify deficiencies and corrective actions; 
(ii)  review  the  financial  objectives,  financial  sustainability,  and  cost-recovery 
mechanisms (when appropriate) of the project; 
(iii)  identify  key  financial  objectives  and  select  appropriate  performance 
measurement indicators and covenants; 
(iv)  prepare project cost estimates and tables in detail, and financing plan; 
(v)  confirm with the Government the Government's counterpart contribution and 
other cofinancing resources, including, if appropriate, the contributions of the 
concerned local government units; 
(vi)  prepare, if appropriate, financial projections and assist the health economist in 
preparing financial cost-benefit analysis, and sensitivity and risk analyses; 
(vii)  review  accounting  policies,  determine  financial  reporting  requirements  and 
timetable, and auditing arrangements; and 
(viii)  assess the governance aspects and suggest related loan covenants. 
 
9.  Social Marketing 
 
16.  One domestic social marketing expert will be engaged for 2 months. A group of local 
facilitators with experience in social marketing will assist the consultant in implementing a social 
marketing campaign. The consultant will 
(i)  Prepare and implement an information campaign on HSRA, using participatory 
workshops, in the 11 convergence sites identified by DOH for the first phase of 
the TA; 
(ii)  train a group of facilitators in social marketing on HSRA to assist in implementing 
the information campaign; 
(iii)  conduct research on knowledge, attitudes, beliefs, motivations, and practices of 
the various stakeholders of HSRA. One group of stakeholders is responsible for 
developing  and  implementing  HSRA  and  includes  political  leaders,  policy 
makers,  health  service  providers,  national  government  officials,  and  local 
government executives. The other group comprises the clients of the health 
services delivery system and the beneficiaries of HSRA; 
(iv)  define required commitments from major stakeholders for implementing HSRA in 
the selected convergence sites; 
(v)  develop  a  medium-term  social  marketing  strategy  using  the  findings  of  the 
research. The strategy will give details on the specific activities that will promote 
desired behavior in the beneficiaries and constituencies; 
(vi)  develop a plan for implementing a medium-term communication campaign that 
defines the timelines for phasing in the campaign as well as reflects resource 
requirements;

team, concerned local government units, and other partners who will be involved 
in the implementation of the social marketing activities; and 
(viii)  consolidate and document outputs with specific recommendations to improve 
support for HSRA. 
 
10.  Poverty and Social Analysis Specialist 
 
17.  One domestic expert in social analysis will be engaged for 2 months to prepare an initial 
poverty and social assessment (IPSA) as outlined in the ADB's Handbook on Poverty and 
Social Analysis. The expert will have a strong background in relevant social science areas. 
He/she will act as adviser on social and poverty policies and will ensure that the design of the 
proposed project is socially sound, equitable and sustainable. 
 
18.  Specifically, the specialist in poverty and social analysis will  
(i)  identify how the proposed project relates to national priorities as identified in the 
country poverty analysis, and in the sectors identified in the Poverty Partnership 
Agreement between the Philippines and ADB; 
(ii)  assist the team leader in identifying key stakeholders, particularly the poor and 
vulnerable groups, and their project-related interests; identify the likely barriers to 
their  participation  in,  and  benefit  from,  the  project,  and  suggest  possible 
strategies for addressing their concerns. Prepare a stakeholder analysis and a 
draft participation plan according to the Handbook; 
(iii)  identify  suitable  NGOs/community-based organizations (CBOs) to establish a 
dialogue. Explore possibilities for involving NGOs/CBOs in project preparation; 
(iv)  facilitate participation of all stakeholders in the preparation of the project, and 
assist the team leader in preparing a series of participatory workshops to inform 
and consult all stakeholders; 
(v)  provide rapid training on participatory workshops to a group of local facilitators 
who will assist in implementing the workshops; 
(vi)  assist the public health specialist to develop a survey to collect data on the most 
common health problems, stratified by income levels; 
(vii)  prepare the IPSA for the proposed project; 
(viii)  prepare a poverty impact assessment and a distributional analysis of the project 
proposal ; in particular, prepare a preliminary assessment of whether the benefits 
of the proposed project will flow primarily to poor or the non-poor; 
(ix)  prepare a gender analysis of the project according to the guidelines in Handbook 
of Poverty and Social Analysis and identify project design elements that will allow 
women to participate in and benefit from the project; 
(x)  assess whether vulnerable groups will be worse off as a result of the project, and 
assess  the  necessity  for  mitigating  measures  and  make  appropriate 
recommendations;  
(xi)  assist the team leader in determining the scale and scope for further detailed 
poverty and social analysis to make project design more pro-poor; and  
(xii)  determine and justify project poverty classification.
